abstract.p: Paul G Allen and Nathan Myhrvold donate $12.5 million to SETI Institute to fund search for intelligent life beyond Earth (S)

block.p: Paul G. Allen, co-founder of Microsoft, and Nathan Myhrvold, the former chief technology officer, don't limit their philanthropic ventures to this planet. Together, they are donating $12.5 million to the SETI Institute, the world's largest private organization searching for intelligent life beyond Earth. SETI, based in Mountain View, Calif., will use the money for a telescope to seek out signals from space. The telescope will have technology that lets it examine up to a dozen stars simultaneously.

''This telescope will be the world's most powerful instrument for the search of intelligent life beyond Earth,'' Mr. Allen, who donated $11.5 million, said in a statement. ''I am pleased to support its important work.''

Mr. Myhrvold, who gave $1 million, is among the scientists who designed the telescope. He, too, is optimistic about finding life outside the planet. The device, announced as the One Hectare Telescope, for its size, has been renamed the Allen Telescope Array.
